children.name: when sb accidentally falls from a standing position
fall
children.definition: /fɔːl/  toaccidentallyfall from a standing position: ngã
examples: ▪ she was going up the stairs when she fell.
▪ george held on tightly, afraid that he might fall.
fall down the stairs/steps etc ngã xuống cầu thang, bậc thang
▪ there was concern for the queen mother yesterday after she fell down a short flight of steps at the airport.

children.name: fall over/down
children.definition: /ˌfɔːl ˈəʊvəʳ, ˈdaʊn/  to fall onto thegroundfrom a standing position:
examples: ngã xuống đất
▪ ben fell down and scraped his knee.
▪ beginning skiers can expect to fall down a lot.
▪ the pavement was slippery and it was easy to fall over.

children.name: have a fall
children.definition: /ˌhæv ə ˈfɔːl/  british if someone, especially an old person, has a fall, they fall and hurt themselves: té ngã (người già yếu)
examples: ▪ my neighbour has had a fall and broken a rib.
▪ grandma had a bad fall in the snow that winter.

children.name: tumble
children.definition: /ˈtʌmbəl/  to fall quickly down a slope or down stairs, rolling over and over and unable to stop: lộn nhào
examples: tumble down/off/into etc lộn nhào xuống, khỏi, vào
▪ she tumbled down the stairs and landed in a heap at the bottom.
▪ a bus veered off the road and tumbled down the hill into the river below.

children.name: fall flat on your face
children.definition: /fɔːl ˌflæt ɒn jɔːʳ ˈfeɪs/  to fall over suddenly so that you are lying on your front on the ground, especially in a way that makes you look funny: té lăn quay
examples: ▪ she fell flat on her face getting out of the car.
▪ the last time i wore high-heeled shoes i fell flat on my face outside a restaurant.

children.name: collapse
children.definition: /kəˈlæps/  to fall suddenly and heavily onto the ground, into a chair etc, because of tiredness, illness, or injury: ngã khuỵ
examples: ▪ one of the horses collapsed from exhaustion after the race.
collapse on ngã khuỷ lên
▪ cohen was hospitalized after he collapsed on the floor and briefly lost consciousness.
collapse into ngã khuỵ vào
▪ milligan collapsed into a chair, sighing deeply.
collapse[singular noun] ngã khuỵ
▪ after stephen’s sudden collapse during the meeting, he was rushed to the hospital.

children.name: keel over
children.definition: /ˌkiːl ˈəʊvəʳ/  to suddenly fall to the ground, because you are ill or have had a shock: ngất xỉu
examples: ▪ she’d been complaining of a headache all morning, and suddenly she just keeled over.
▪ carson keeled over and died in front of the nightclub after taking a number of illegal drugs.

children.name: go head over heels
children.definition: /gəʊ ˌhed əʊvəʳ ˈhiːlz/  to fall forward with so much force that you roll over: ngã sầm
examples: ▪ she slipped on the polished floor and went head over heels.
▪ shelly’s horse stepped into soft sand and went down, horse and rider going head over heels in a cloud of dust.

children.name: when an upright object, a building, a wall, etc falls
fall
children.definition: /fɔːl/
examples: đổ, sụp
▪ she was playing just yards from where the building fell.
fall across/onto/on top of độ sụp xuống, lên phía trên của
▪ a tree had fallen across the road and blocked it.
fall off/out of/from đổ ra khỏi, từ
▪ the days were getting shorter and the leaves had started falling from the trees
▪ i can’t find my passport - it must have fallen out of my pocket.
fallen[adjective only before noun] đổ
▪ fallen trees blocked the railway tracks.

children.name: fall over
children.definition: /ˌfɔːl ˈəʊvəʳ/  if a tall object falls over, it falls onto its side from an upright position: ngã xuống
examples: ▪ that bookcase looks as if it’s about to fall over.
▪ there was no wind; the tree just fell over.

children.name: fall down
children.definition: /ˌfɔːl ˈdaʊn/  if abuilding,wall, orfencefalls down, part or all of it falls to the ground, because it is inbadconditionor because it has beendamaged:
examples: đổ sụp
▪ a boy was injured yesterday when part of a wall fell down near to where he was playing.
▪ a large tree fell down during a windstorm and damaged our car.

children.name: collapse
children.definition: /kəˈlæps/  if abuilding,walletc collapses, it suddenly falls down, especially because of asuddenpressure:
examples: đổ sập
▪ our tent collapsed in the middle of the night.
▪ the building was badly damaged in the explosion, and rescue workers are worried that it may collapse.
▪ minutes later the second tower collapsed.

children.name: fall in
children.definition: /ˌfɔːl ˈɪn/  if a roof falls in, it falls to the ground inside the building: rơi
examples: ▪ during the hurricane the roof fell in.
fall in on rơi lên
▪ we need to fix the ceiling before it falls in on us.

children.name: cave in
children.definition: /ˌkeɪv ˈɪn/  if a roof, wall etc caves in, it suddenly and heavily falls inwards especially because it is weak and in bad condition: sụp
examples: ▪ the roof has caved in, so the whole building has been declared unsafe.
cave in on sụp xuống
▪ wooden beams support the roof, preventing it from caving in on the miners.

children.name: topple over
children.definition: /ˌtɒpəl ˈəʊvəʳǁˌtɑː-/  if something topples over, it moves unsteadily backwards and forwards then falls to the ground: sụp đổ
examples: ▪ the little boy put one more brick on the tower and it toppled over.
▪ that plant’s going to topple over if you don’t put it in a bigger pot.

children.name: tip over
children.definition: /ˌtɪp ˈəʊvəʳ/  to suddenly turn and fall to the ground as a result of not being properly balanced: té nhào
examples: ▪ i sat on the edge of the table, and the whole thing tipped over.
▪ the fire started when a lamp tipped over and ignited a cloth sofa.

children.name: knock sb over/down
children.definition: knock somebody over/knock somebody down/ˌnɒk somebody ˈəʊvəʳ, ˌnɒk somebody ˈdaʊnǁˌnɑːk-/  to push or hit someone hard, so that they fall to the ground:
examples: dẩy, húc, đánh ngã ..
knock somebody over/down đánh gục ai đó
▪ careful where you’re going! you nearly knocked me over!
▪ in the rush to get out of the building, she was knocked down.knock down/over somebody
▪ some of the bigger boys purposely knock over the smaller ones.

children.name: trip ( up )
children.definition: tripalso trip up/trɪp, ˌtrɪp ˈʌp/ british /trɪp, ˌtrɪp ˌʌp/  to make someone fall or almost fall by putting yourfootor another object in their way:
examples: đạp ngã
▪ one of the runners claimed she had been tripped.
trip somebody up đạp ai đó ngã
▪ one man tripped me up and the other one grabbed my handbag.

children.name: push sb over
children.definition: push somebody over/ˌpʊʃ somebody ˈəʊvəʳ/  to deliberately push someone with your hand so that they fall to the ground: đẩy ai đó ngã
examples: ▪ another little kid came and pushed him over onto the grass.

children.name: knock sb to the ground
children.definition: knock somebody to the ground/ˌnɒk somebody tə ðə ˈgraʊnd ǁ ˌnɑːk-/  to hit someone so hard that they lose their balance and fall to the ground: đánh ngã xuống đất
examples: ▪ a teenage boy knocked him to the ground and ran off with his briefcase.

children.name: make st fall or let it fall
drop
children.definition: /drɒpǁdrɑːp/  to stop holding something so that it falls, especiallyaccidentally:
examples: đánh rơi
▪ watch you don’t drop that box - it’s very heavy.
▪ her hands shake constantly and she keeps dropping things.
▪ you dropped your toy. do you want it back?
drop something on/onto something đánh rơi cái gì lên cái gì
▪ margaret dropped the letters onto her desk.

children.name: knock over
children.definition: /ˌnɒk ˈəʊvəʳǁˌnɑːk-/  to hit something so that it falls onto its side from an upright position, especially when you do thisaccidentally:
examples: làm đổ
knock something over làm cái gì đổ
▪ be careful or you’ll knock the vase over.
knock over something làm đổ cái gì
▪ he bumped into the table and knocked over the candle.

children.name: spill
children.definition: /spɪl/  toaccidentallylet liquid, powder, or small pieces of something fall onto a surface and spread out over it:
examples: làm tràn, đánh đổ ( nước )
▪ oops, i just spilled my water.
spill something down/all over/onto something làm tràn cái gì xuống, lên khắp, vào cái gì
▪ ‘how was the party?’ ‘ok, but some idiot spilled wine all over my new dress.’
▪ aaron spilled all the popcorn on the floor.

children.name: tip over
children.definition: /ˌtɪp ˈəʊvəʳ/  to make something fall over, usually accidentally, by making it lose balance: ngã nhào
examples: tip something over làm ngã nhào cái gì
▪ the cat managed to tip the christmas tree over.
tip over something ngã nhào vào cái gì
▪ he accidentally tipped over a candle, and the tablecloth caught fire.

children.name: overturn
children.definition: /ˌəʊvəʳˈtɜːʳn/  to make something fall on its side or turn something over completely, especially by pushing it very hard: đẩy ngược
examples: ▪ the wind was so strong that it overturned dustbins and wrecked fences.
▪ protestors overturned cars and set fire to them.

children.name: upset
children.definition: /ʌpˈset/  to accidentally knock or push something over, so that its contents fall out and spread over a wide area: đánh đổ
examples: ▪ one of the kids upset a bottle of water on the table.

children.name: to almost fall from a standing position
trip
children.definition: alsotripoverbritish /trɪp, ˌtrɪp ˈəʊvəʳ/  toaccidentallyhit something with your foot when you are walking or running, so that you fall or nearly fall:
examples: vấp chân
▪ i didn’t push him - he tripped.
▪ she’d had quite a lot to drink and kept tripping over.
trip over vấp vào
▪ pick up that box -- someone might trip over it.
trip on vấp lên
▪ her medical problems began when she tripped on a rug and broke her hip.
trip and fall vấp và té
▪ one boy tripped and fell into the water.

children.name: slip
children.definition: /slɪp/  toaccidentallyslide on a wet or smooth surface, so that you fall or nearly fall:
examples: trượt chân
▪ be careful you don’t slip - the floor’s wet.
slip on trượt trên
▪ she slipped on the icy sidewalk and grabbed will’s arm to steady herself.
slip and fall trượt và té ngã
▪ i walked slowly through the mud, trying not to slip and fall.

children.name: stumble
children.definition: /ˈstʌmbəl/  to nearly fall down when you are walking or running, because you do not put your foot down carefully or because something is in the way:
examples: suýt ngã , sẩy chân
▪ in her hurry, eva stumbled and dropped the tray she was carrying.
stumble on/over sẩy chân trên
▪ mason headed towards the house, stumbling on the rough ground.

children.name: lose your balance
children.definition: /ˌluːz jɔːʳ ˈbæləns/  to fall or nearly fall, when you need to balance carefully to remain in an upright position, for example when you are standing on a ladder or riding a bicycle:
examples: mất thăng bằng
▪ i tried to help gina up, but i lost my balance and we both fell into the stream.
▪ bill was leaning over to watch, and lost his balance.

children.name: lose your footing
children.definition: /ˌluːz jɔːʳ ˈfʊtɪŋ/  to lose your balance because your foot slips, especially when you are walking or climbing over an uneven or slippery surface: mất thăng bằng
examples: ▪ i lost my footing on the snowy bank and fell into the river.
▪ a climber who lost his footing was taken to hospital with serious injuries.

children.name: to fall through the air to the ground
fall
children.definition: /fɔːl/  ngã
examples: ▪ one of the climbers fell fifty feet.
▪ a light rain was falling.
fall out/into/from etc ngã khỏi, ngã vào, ngã từ
▪ she opened the cupboard and everything fell out.
▪ there should be spaces between the boards of the deck to allow debris to fall through.
▪ fred fell out of the tree and broke his arm.
▪ the girl had fallen from a fourth-floor window, but was not badly hurt.
fall on ngã lên
▪ careful that box doesn’t fall on you, charlotte!

children.name: fall off
children.definition: /ˌfɔːl ˈɒf/  to accidentally fall from something in a high position to the ground: ngã xuống đất
examples: ▪ jim was laughing so hard he fell off his chair.
▪ a bag of groceries fell off the table onto the floor.

children.name: plunge
children.definition: /plʌndʒ/  to suddenly fall a long way from somewhere high up: phóng xuống
examples: ▪ the aeroplane’s engines failed and it plunged into the ocean.
plunge off/down/into etc phóng khỏi, phóng xuống, phóng vào
▪ their car swerved to avoid a truck, and plunged off the cliff.
plunge to your deathfall a long way and be killed lao mình tìm chết
▪ a skydiver plunged to his death yesterday when his parachute failed to open.

children.name: plummet
children.definition: /ˈplʌmɪt, ˈplʌmət/  to fall from somewhere high up, very quickly and very directly: lao thẳng xuống
examples: ▪ the rope snapped, causing the climber to plummet several hundred feet down the mountain.
▪ two aircraft on a training flight collided and plummeted to the ground.

children.name: drop
children.definition: /drɒpǁdrɑːp/  to fall suddenly from a high place straight down onto or towards the ground: rơi
examples: drop onto/to/from etc rơi vào, rơi từ
▪ two bottles rolled across the table, dropped onto the floor, and smashed.
▪ a few pine cones had already dropped to the ground.

children.name: tumble
children.definition: /ˈtʌmbəl/  to fall quickly through the air, rolling over and over: lộn nhào
examples: tumble down/off/from etc lộn nhào xuống, khỏi, từ
▪ a little girl tumbled about 30 feet from the window of her family’s third-floor apartment.

children.name: come down
children.definition: /ˌkʌm ˈdaʊn/  if rain, snow etc comes down, it falls heavily: rơi dày
examples: ▪ we can’t go out now -- the rain’s really coming down.
▪ snow was coming down so thickly i could barely see through the window.
come downphrasal verbland
to fall on the ground
_a lot of trees came down in the storm.
_the snow came down during the night.

children.name: to fall off a horse, bicycle etc
fall off
children.definition: /ˌfɔːl ˈɒf/  to accidentally fall from something you are riding on, for example a horse or a bicycle: ngã khỏi
examples: ▪ he fell off his bike and broke his wrist.
▪ a bolt broke on an amusement park ride, and several children who fell off were seriously injured.

children.name: be thrown
children.definition: /biː ˈθrəʊn/  to fall off a horse or similar animal because of a violent or sudden movement: ném
examples: ▪ rodeo riders can suffer appalling injuries after being thrown by bulls and steers.
be thrown from bị ném đi khỏi
▪ he broke his neck when he was thrown from a horse.
